channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Invaded Russia. Here’s What It Was Like for Civilians.
item.description: Russians in the area of Ukraine’s invasion have described seeing signs of violent encounters, as well as respectful treatment from Ukrainian troops.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Haley Willis, Ekaterina Bodyagina, Oleg Matsnev and Dmitriy Khavin
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: People who evacuated from the border region around Kursk, Russia, waiting for aid to be distributed in August.

item.title: Living on a Volcano’s Edge, Italians Practice for Disaster
item.description: The Italian authorities carried out a drill of their plan to save a half-million people from toxic fumes, deadly quakes or a full eruption. Vesuvius isn’t the volcano they’re worried about.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Alessandro Penso for The New York Times
item.media:description: Italian Air Force cadets at the Accademia Aeronautica in Pozzuoli, Italy, boarding buses as part of an evacuation simulation this month.

item.title: How Years of Government Failure Led to Nigeria’s Worst Flood in Decades
item.description: After a recent dam disaster, Nigerian officials blamed God, climate change and poor people. But experts had warned the dam was at risk well before it collapsed. The officials did nothing.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean, Ismail Alfa and Fati Abubakar

item.title: Live Updates: Iran’s Leaders Stress Their Right to Respond to Israel’s Strikes
item.description: Ayatollah Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader, appeared to strike a measured tone. He said Israel’s attack should not be “magnified or downplayed,” state media reported.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Tropical Storm Trami Hits Vietnam After Killing Dozens in the Philippines
item.description: The storm made landfall near Danang on Sunday after leaving at least 80 people dead last week.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young and Camille Elemia
item.media:description: Firefighters digging through mud and debris in the Philippine province of Batangas on Saturday.

item.title: For Catholic Jubilee, Days of Joy and Sadness in Rome and Bethlehem
item.description: For Rome, the rare Christmas Eve rite of redemption is cause for celebration this year. For Bethlehem, it is another grim reminder of the generations of war and deprivation.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Church of the Nativity in the West Bank city of Bethlehem.

item.title: Uruguay’s 2024 Election: Candidates, Issues and Predictions
item.description: Crime, child poverty and an aging population are top issues as voters in one of Latin America’s most stable democracies head to the polls on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Laurence Blair
item.media:description: José Mujica, a former president of Uruguay, voting at a polling station in Montevideo, the country’s capital, during primary elections in June.

item.title: Hundreds Killed in Days in Sudan as War Surges
item.description: Paramilitary forces ransacked villages and killed hundreds of people, activists said, hastening calls for the United Nations to deploy a mission to protect civilians.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir, Declan Walsh and Abdalrahman Altayeb
item.media:description: Airstrikes sent smoke billowing above Khartoum, Sudan’s capital, this month as the Sudanese Army attacked positions held by paramilitaries.

item.title: The Man Who Shaped China’s Strongman Rule Has a New Job: Winning Taiwan
item.description: Xi Jinping’s top adviser, Wang Huning, is credited with shaping the authoritarianism that steered China’s rise. But can he influence Taiwan?
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.media:description: Wang Huning in 2022.

item.title: At Vatican Synod, Women’s Issues Are Relegated to a Side Group
item.description: A meeting four years in the making said the ordination of women required further study, but it called for women to have more leadership roles, even in seminaries.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: The 16th General Assembly of the Synod of Bishops at the Vatican on Monday.

item.title: Who Is Tommy Robinson, the Far-Right Activist Behind a London Rally?
item.description: The founder of the English Defence League, whose real name is Stephen Yaxley-Lennon, is at the forefront of a growing movement that was behind anti-immigrant riots this summer.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Tommy Robinson, whose real name is Stephen Yaxley-Lennon, at Folkestone Police Station on Friday. He will be held in custody until a court hearing on Monday.

item.title: Republic of Georgia’s Ruling Party Claims Election Victory
item.description: The Georgian Dream party won 54 percent of the vote, the electoral commission said Sunday, a result that critics of the government fear could derail the country’s pro-Western course.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Supporters of the governing Georgian Dream party celebrating in the streets of Tbilisi, Georgia’s capital, after parliamentary elections on Saturday.

item.title: Israel’s Strike Marks New Phase of Conflict, but Stops Short of All-Out War
item.description: Iran’s initial reaction suggested that the sides had once again averted an uncontrolled war, even if the prospect looms larger than ever.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Looking out over Tehran after hearing explosions early on Saturday.

item.title: In Deciding Whether to Retaliate, Iran Faces a Dilemma
item.description: If Iran strikes back at Israel, it risks further escalation at a time when its economy is struggling and its military is vulnerable. If it doesn’t, it risks looking weak.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A view of Tehran after explosions were heard on Saturday during an attack on Iran by Israel.

item.title: For First Time in Decades, Japan Votes in a Knife-Edge Election
item.description: The Japanese electorate seemed poised to punish the Liberal Democrats, even if it does not go so far as to hand power to the opposition.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich, Kiuko Notoya and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: Voting in Tokyo on Sunday. Many Japanese are frustrated by a sense that all their political options are uninspiring and that the governing party is complacent.

item.title: Israel Struck Air Defenses Around Critical Iranian Energy Sites, Officials Say
item.description: Israeli attacks hit air-defense systems around important energy sites but avoided the facilities themselves, Iranian and Israeli officials said. The United States had urged Israel not to strike energy and oil facilities.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tehran after multiple sounds of explosions early Saturday.

item.title: The Curious Case of a Temple Sweet: How Food Increasingly Divides India
item.description: A Hindu politician has accused his Christian predecessor of allowing a temple’s sanctity to be violated with an animal product.
item.dc:creator: Pragati K.B.
item.media:description: Making laddu in Kolkata, India. A political storm has arisen in southern India after a politician charged that adulterated ghee was used in making the sweet for a prominent Hindu temple.

item.title: What We Know About Israel’s Strikes On Iran
item.description: After military-on-military attacks, will Israel and Iran be able to contain their conflict? Maria Abi-Habib, an investigative correspondent for The New York Times, looks at an unprecedented new chapter in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib, Christina Shaman, Nikolay Nikolov and Laura Salaberry

item.title: Why Are North Korean Troops in Russia?
item.description: Over the last month, North Korea’s role aiding Russia in its war in Ukraine has significantly escalated. U.S. officials reported that North Korean soldiers are already operating in the Kursk region in western Russia, where Ukrainian forces are staging a counteroffensive. Michael Shear, a White House correspondent for The New York Times, explains what the deeping relationship between Russia and North Korea means for the war in Ukraine and the world.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Nikolay Nikolov and Laura Salaberry

item.title: U.K. Man Who Posed as a Girl to Extort Teens Online Gets 20 Years in Prison
item.description: The Northern Ireland resident sought explicit images from thousands of girls he had groomed and blackmailed, leading to the death of a 12-year-old girl in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Brian Lawless/PA Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Detective Chief Superintendent Eamonn Corrigan, with the Northern Ireland police, speaking to reporters outside the Belfast Crown Court on Friday.

item.title: Israeli Attack Puts Iranians on Edge: ‘The Vibe Is Not Normal’
item.description: A sense of uncertainty prevailed in Iran after an Israeli retaliatory strike. Explosions kept some awake, while others hoped life would go back to normal.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Tehran on Saturday after the Israeli strikes on Iran.

item.title: Is Canada’s New Immigration Policy Really the End of an Era?
item.description: Critics say the review of the permanent and temporary residents’ programs amounts to the abandonment of decades of “welcome mat” policy. But globally, Canada is still peerless in its openness.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: The author on assignment in Brampton, Ontario.

item.title: Global Economic Leaders Confront a New Era of Industrial Policy
item.description: Policymakers brace for more protectionism and the demise of “neoliberalism” if Donald J. Trump is re-elected in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Kristalina Georgieva, the International Monetary Fund’s managing director. For years the I.M.F. pushed for open borders and global flows of money and goods, but that view is facing growing resistance.

item.title: A Skeleton Bank of Understudied Species
item.description: With a new database of medical images, zoo and wildlife vets can finally see what healthy uncommon animals, from rhinos and tamarins to pangolins and sea stars, should look like on the inside.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: Iran’s State Media Plays Down Israeli Attacks
item.description: Explosions woke Iranians up and rattled their windows as strikes targeted sites in at least three provinces.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A view of Tehran early on Saturday.

item.title: As U.S. Election Looms, Biden Aides Struggle With Middle East Wars
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken tried to get Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to envision a U.S.-backed plan for ending the war in Gaza, but there was no sign of progress.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken arriving in Doha, Qatar, on Thursday. It was his 11th wartime trip to the region.

item.title: Why Did Israel Attack Iran?
item.description: The two countries have been fighting a shadow war for years. Now, their conflict has burst into the open.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: The ruins of a building in Hod Hasharon, Israel, early this month after it was hit by a missile from Iran.

item.title: North Korean Troops Assemble in Russia’s Kursk Region, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: Thousands of soldiers from an elite unit of the Korean People’s Army began arriving on Wednesday and are expected to try to help expel Ukrainian forces from Russian territory.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: A military parade in Pyongyang, North Korea. Soldiers from an elite unit of the Korean People’s Army have begun arriving in the Kursk region of Russia, according to two U.S. officials.

item.title: Videos Appear to Show North Korean Troops in Russia Amid Ukraine War
item.description: Footage was filmed in the Russian Far East, which the United States says is hosting thousands of North Korean soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun, Arijeta Lajka, Christoph Koettl and Shawn Paik

item.title: Media Organizations Criticize Israeli Strike That Killed Three Journalists
item.description: Israel says it was bombing a structure associated with Hezbollah and says it is reviewing the strike.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A car marked “Press” at the site of an Israeli airstrike on an area where a number of journalists were staying, in the southern Lebanese village of Hasbaya, on Wednesday.

item.title: In Iran’s Capital, Murals Offer Tributes and Threats Against Israel
item.description: In the Iranian capital’s Palestine Square, a series of murals have telegraphed warnings to the country’s enemies.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Arash Khamooshi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A banner threatening Israel with the slogan “Prepare your coffins,” written in Hebrew and in Farsi, on a building Palestine Square in Tehran in January.

item.title: Gang Gunfire in Haiti Hits U.S. Embassy Vehicles and U.N. Helicopter
item.description: The attacks this week point to an escalation of violence as the situation worsens and gangs overwhelm security forces, including a multinational force.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: Trucks blocked a road this week in Port-au-Prince, Haiti’s capital, as heavily armed gangs continued trying to gain territory.

item.title: Israel Pummels Gaza and Lebanon With Hundreds of Deadly Airstrikes
item.description: Gaza’s health ministry reported that dozens of people had been killed in a residential area of Khan Younis, as Israel launched a barrage of attacks across the region on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack, Raja Abdulrahim, Euan Ward and Thomas Fuller
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: The remains of destroyed buildings following Israeli airstrikes on Friday in Khan Younis, in southern Gaza.

item.title: U.N. Warns of ‘Atrocity Crimes’ in Gaza, and Jordan Accuses Israel of ‘Ethnic Cleansing’
item.description: Jordan’s foreign minister, Ayman Safadi, appearing with Secretary of State Antony Blinken, said that Israel was conducting “ethnic cleansing” in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, left, met with Jordan’s foreign minister, Ayman Safadi, in London on Friday.

item.title: Chinese Hackers Are Said to Have Targeted Phones Used by Trump and Vance
item.description: The targeting of the Republican presidential ticket’s phones is part of what appears to be a wide-ranging effort to gather information about American leaders.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett, Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:description: The type of data targeted by hackers from phones used by former President Donald J. Trump and his running mate, Senator JD Vance of Ohio, could be a gold mine for a foreign intelligence agency.

item.title: Russia Could Expand Its Assistance to Houthis, U.S. Says
item.description: The group’s attacks in the Red Sea have driven up shipping costs and forced the United States and its allies to increase their naval presence in the region.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Russia could add missiles to the list of armaments they have supplied to the Houthi rebels in Yemen.

item.title: Has Hezbollah Been Weakened by Israel’s Recent Attacks?
item.description: Despite losing leaders and weapons stockpiles, the militant group remains resilient, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Israel’s Iron Dome missile defense system, seen from Haifa, Israel, intercepting rockets launched from inside Lebanon earlier this month.

item.title: W.H.O Says It Has Lost Contact With Key Gaza Hospital After Israeli Raid
item.description: The facility, Kamal Adwan Hospital, was one of the last functioning hospitals in the north of the enclave.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack, Raja Abdulrahim and Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:description: Palestinians in the trauma ward at Kamal Adwan Hospital in Beit Lahia, northern Gaza, on Thursday.

item.title: Arsenal-Liverpool: Can Trent Alexander-Arnold Defend?
item.description: Is the Liverpool star a good defender? It depends on your evidence.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith

item.title: Russia Raises Interest Rate to 21 Percent, Its Highest in Decades
item.description: Military spending and recruitment are causing the country’s economy to overheat, leaving regulators in a struggle to rein in rising prices.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: An electronic screen showing a military recruitment ad in downtown Moscow on Friday. War-related costs are helping to feed inflation.

item.title: BRICS Summit Offers a Glimpse Inside Putin’s Alternate Reality
item.description: At a meeting of emerging economies, Vladimir Putin positioned himself as a respected and powerful leader, ignoring the condemnation he receives from the West.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, center, and other BRICS summit participants in Kazan, Russia, on Thursday.

item.title: 5 Israeli Soldiers Are Killed Amid Hezbollah Clashes in Lebanon
item.description: As clashes with Hezbollah militants intensified, Israel’s public broadcaster reported that the soldiers had been killed when a rocket struck a building they were in.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers carry the coffin for one of five Israeli soldiers killed while fighting in southern Lebanon.

item.title: Here are the latest developments.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Ronen Bergman and Farnaz Fassihi

item.title: Canada’s Sikh Communities Have Been Rocked by Violence. Authorities Blame India.
item.description: Tightly knit communities in Ontario and British Columbia have been rocked by violent events in the past 18 months. Now the authorities say the Indian government was behind them.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sikhs at a temple in Brampton, a city near Toronto with a large Sikh population. Acts of intimidation and violence there have been documented in court records.

item.title: Attacks on L.G.B.T.Q. People in Ivory Coast Shake Sense of Security
item.description: Ivory Coast, long considered one of West Africa’s most tolerant societies, has recently seen a string of assaults on L.G.B.T.Q. people after several social media influencers exhorted their followers to “hunt” gay men.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Arlette Bashizi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A market in Abidjan, Ivory Coast, where crowds of young men went on an anti-gay rampage last month.

item.title: The Other War for These Gazans Is Against Cancer
item.description: The small number of cancer patients from Gaza who are receiving care in Jordan’s capital, Amman, bear burdens beyond those of illness — deep feelings of guilt, along with fear and homesickness.
item.dc:creator: Laura Boushnak and Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: They had escaped a war zone, but in many ways, the fight for life was just beginning.

item.title: Georgia’s Election Could Be a Turning Point for the Caucasus Nation: What to Know
item.description: A parliamentary vote could decide whether the Caucasus nation will be oriented to the West or East for years to come. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Election billboards for the governing Georgian Dream party in Tbilisi, Georgia. Some juxtaposed scenes of Ukraine with Georgia to indicate a choice between war and peace.

item.title: Israeli Strike Kills 3 Journalists in Southern Lebanon
item.description: The three worked for Lebanese news organizations, their employers said. Lebanon’s health ministry said they had been staying in a residence housing journalists.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Euan Ward
item.media:description: Red Cross workers carrying bodies after an Israeli strike in southern Lebanon on Friday killed three journalists.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Stars Rally for Harris
item.description: Plus, an interview with the Taliban’s most fearsome leader.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:description: Kamala Harris, Bruce Springsteen and Barack Obama backstage in Georgia yesterday.

item.title: In a Region of Majestic Beauty, Sunnis and Shiites Wage Bloody War
item.description: In Kurram, near the Afghan border, Pakistan has been helpless to stop the latest outbreaks of a sectarian conflict that goes back decades.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:description: A funeral in the Kurram district of Pakistan in October for Sunni Muslims killed in sectarian fighting.

item.title: Malaria Is Surging in Ethiopia, Reversing a Decade of Progress Against the Disease
item.description: Climate change, civil conflict and growing resistance to insecticides and treatments are all contributing to an alarming spread of cases.
item.dc:creator: Maya Misikir and Stephanie Nolen
item.media:credit: Tiksa Negeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: An entomologist collecting mosquitoes for study from the Butuji River in Dire Dawa, Ethiopia, last year.

item.title: Iran Prepares for War but Hopes to Avert One as It Braces for Israeli Strikes
item.description: Tehran has several plans for responding to a threatened retaliatory strike by Israel, depending on its severity, and might also do nothing, insiders say.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iranians honoring the slain leaders of Hamas and Hezbollah in Tehran on Thursday. Both were killed by Israel.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Stars Rally for Harris
item.description: Plus, an interview with the Taliban’s most fearsome leader.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: Barack Obama and Eminem at a rally for Kamala Harris on Tuesday.

item.title: Why Is North Korea Deploying Troops to Help Russia? Here’s What to Know.
item.description: The move gives Kim Jong-un, the leader of North Korea, leverage to ask President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia for a lot in return.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Gavriil Grigorov/Sputnik, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo provided by Russian state media showing President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia with Kim Jong-un of North Korea at an event in Pyongyang in June.

item.title: Gaza Cease-Fire Talks to Resume, but No Sign Yet That Hamas Will Take Part
item.description: Israel and the United States plan to send envoys next week to negotiations in Qatar, as the related wars in Gaza and Lebanon rage on.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley, Raja Abdulrahim and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Prime Minister Mohammed bin Abdulrahman bin Jassim al-Thani of Qatar in Doha on Thursday.

item.title: Turkey Seeks Opening With Kurdish Militants Despite Attack on Aerospace Company
item.description: Recent gestures by Turkish leaders suggest the possibility of new peace talks with the group fighting for Kurdish autonomy.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
item.media:description: Supporters of a pro-Kurdish party in Turkey displayed banners with a portrait of jailed Kurdish militant leader Abdullah Ocalan at a rally in March.

item.title: Michael Jackson, British General Who Disobeyed U.S. Superior, Dies at 80
item.description: Labeled “the Prince of Darkness,” he refused to follow an order by NATO’s commander during the Balkans war, saying, “It’s not worth starting World War III.”
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:description: Gen. Mike Jackson in 2015. His British Army career extended from Northern Ireland to the Balkans to the Iraq war.

item.title: Canada Tightens Immigration After Years of Expansion
item.description: Saying that Canada had invited too many newcomers in, in too short a period of time, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced lower targets to slow population growth.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: One in five Canadians were born overseas and polling shows that the public broadly supports a well-managed immigration system, but that people have become increasingly concerned about the high number of new immigrants arriving.

item.title: At BRICS, Putin Appears to Say That North Korean Troops Are in Russia
item.description: “If there are images they are a reflection of something,” he said in a tongue-in-cheek answer to whether Pyongyang had sent troops to help with Russia’s war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia did not explicitly confirm or deny remarks made Wednesday by the Pentagon, which said that North Korea had sent troops to Russia.

item.title: Why the World Fears a War Between Israel and Iran
item.description: An all-out war could entangle countries around the world and threaten the global economy.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: A destroyed building in Hod Hasharon, Israel, after an Iranian missile attack earlier this month.

item.title: Chapo Wins Mozambique’s Presidency in Disputed Election
item.description: Daniel Chapo of the Frelimo party, which has governed the southern African nation for nearly 50 years, was declared the victor amid violence and widespread allegations of fraud.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: Supporters of Daniel Chapo, the Frelimo candidate who was declared the winner of Mozambique’s presidential election, in Maputo this month.
